chapter.htmlHeader: How do I know my patient has it?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• In people with suspected acute kidney injury (AKI) who do not require urgent admission to hospital, measure serum creatinine (or refer to a current result if this has already been done) and, taking into account the clinical context, compare with baseline.
    • To obtain a baseline value for the initial detection of acute kidney injury.
      • Use the lowest creatinine value within 7 days of the current value, or (if this is not available),
      • Look at older results and use the lowest or mean creatinine value from between 7 days and 1 year before the current value. 
    • If no baseline creatinine value is available, it may be appropriate to repeat the creatinine measurement after 48–72 hours.
      • Use clinical judgement — monitor the person closely and do not let waiting for a second creatinine result delay treatment or referral if acute kidney injury is possible, particularly if the person is unwell or the serum creatinine level is high.
    • Take into consideration if the person has:
      • Chronic kidney disease — an increase in creatinine may be because this has progressed.
      • Recently been treated with trimethoprim — this can cause a false positive result as trimethoprim may increase serum creatinine, but not affect glomerular filtration rate.
      • Recently completed a pregnancy — this can cause a false positive result due to an apparent rise in creatinine compared with naturally reduced creatinine values in pregnancy.
  • Detect AKI by using any of the following criteria: 
    • A rise in serum creatinine of 26 micromol/L or greater within 48 hours.
      • Be aware that in the absence of a baseline creatinine value, a high serum creatinine level may indicate AKI, even if the rise in creatinine over 48 hours is less than 26 micromol/L (particularly if the person has been unwell for a few days).
    • A 50% or greater rise in serum creatinine (more than 1.5 times baseline) known or presumed to have occurred within the past 7 days.
    • A fall in urine output to less than 0.5 mL/kg/hour for more than 6 hours (if it is possible to measure this, for example, if the person has a catheter).
  • If there is doubt whether a person with chronic kidney disease has worsening of their condition or has acute-on-chronic kidney disease, consider it to be acute and manage accordingly.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Approach to diagnosis of acute kidney injury

  • CKS has based its approach to the diagnosis of acute kidney injury (AKI) largely on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Acute kidney injury: prevention, detection and management [NICE, 2013b].
  • Think Kidneys, a national programme led by NHS England in partnership with the UK Renal Registry, emphasises the importance of interpreting test results taking into account clinical circumstances [Think Kidneys, 2016a; Think Kidneys, 2017]. This is consistent with expert opinion in a review article which states that clinical judgement is required to make the diagnosis of AKI as the clinical situation, underlying cause, and factors affecting the performance of the definition of AKI need to be considered [Selby et al, 2016].

Measurement of serum creatinine

  • NICE recommends measuring serum creatinine and comparing with baseline in adults with acute illness and a risk factor for acute kidney injury [NICE, 2013b].
  • The methods of assessing baseline values for creatinine values available from the past year are consistent with those suggested in the NICE full guideline on acute kidney injury [National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2013] and Think Kidneys in their best practice guidance for primary care [Think Kidneys, 2016a]. In the NICE guideline, a method of calculating a baseline creatinine when a creatinine result is not available is discussed but this has limitations and CKS is of the opinion that its use is not practical for a primary care setting. Therefore in this situation CKS has based its recommendations on consensus expert opinion in Best practice guidance. Responding to AKI warning stage test results for adults in primary care which advises repeating the creatinine level within 48–72 hours to ascertain whether there is a further increase, or the changes are stable and more indicative of chronic kidney disease [Think Kidneys, 2016a]. 
  • Expert opinion from previous reviewers of this CKS topic emphasises the need for close monitoring and clinical judgement regarding a person's clinical state and creatinine level. 

Factors to take into consideration which may affect test results

  • This recommendation is based on consensus expert opinion from Think Kidneys, in a primary care best practice guidance, that explains situations in which false positive results for AKI may be encountered [Think Kidneys, 2016a].

Detection of acute kidney injury

  • There is a lack of a gold standard diagnostic test for AKI and NICE identified no specific evidence for a primary care setting.
    • The RIFLE (Risk, Injury, Failure, Loss and End stage renal disease) criteria were developed by the Acute Dialysis Quality Initiative group in 2004. They were followed in 2007 by the AKIN criteria from the Acute Kidney Injury Network, which built on the RIFLE definition. However, it is accepted that both of these classifications have limitations, and more recently, the International Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes (KDIGO) guideline simplified and merged the two previous definitions [National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2013].
    • In making recommendations, NICE has considered all these criteria and acknowledges the need for a standardized definition of AKI [National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2013]. The NICE detection criteria are supported by subsequent guidance for primary care from Think Kidneys [Think Kidneys, 2016a]. 
  • In response to expert feedback from previous reviewers of this CKS topic, text has been added to raise awareness of the possibility of missing the diagnosis of well-established AKI with a high creatinine level if the rise in serum creatinine level over 48 hours is less than 26 micromol/L.
  • The NICE guideline development group acknowledges that because detection of oliguria is difficult in primary care, practitioners will rely on creatinine changes to detect AKI (and should be aware that small increases in creatinine indicate deterioration in the person's condition) [National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2013]. However CKS has included the criteria for detection based on oliguria as information on urine output may be available for people who already have catheters in primary care, although a Think Kidneys position statement noted that urinary catheterisation to measure hourly urine output should not routinely be used as part of diagnosis of AKI unless in a critical care setting [Think Kidneys, 2016b]. 
  • NICE also discussed the limitations of detection in primary care as primary healthcare professionals may have less information on which to base a judgement due to less frequent monitoring of renal function [National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2013].

Doubt about test results in people with chronic kidney disease

  • The recommendation to treat people with chronic kidney disease as acute-on-chronic if there is a clinical deterioration and there is doubt as to whether the changes are acute or chronic is based on the opinion of the NICE GDG. This states that it can be difficult to distinguish between acute-on-chronic kidney disease and progressive kidney disease and there is little harm if a person with progressive chronic kidney disease is falsely diagnosed as having acute-on-chronic kidney disease [National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2013].
